detailsOfAchievement: Supreme Task is an NGO working towards community development in 18 States of India since 1993. Our goal is to focus on Education and Health as well as social, moral and spiritual well being of people. Not only that, it helps young men and women to explore their talents and use it for the interest of our nation. Most important programs run by Supreme Task are leadership development, equipping and training youth of India, Child Development, Health services and awareness, Education to all and disaster mitigation. We are also working in one of the poorest District (Balangir) of Orissa under KBK districts announced by Govt. of India. Out of various needs of the people of Balangir District, Health is an emerging need owing to lack of medical/health facilities compiled with decreasing health status of people. Drought, less industrialization, unemployment, migration, etc. contributes to the poor health status of people in different Blocks. One 150 bedded Hospital in District headquarter and 13 other Primary Health Centers, which are not properly equipped in terms of manpower and equipment found to be inadequate in meeting the health need of 13,35,760 people of this District. Based on the need, we have taken over an existing Eye Hospital and converted it to 50 bedded General Hospital in Balangir district headquarter. We have a plan to equip this hospital with all latest medical equipments, sufficient manpower and better service facility for the people of this area.

detailsOfAchievement: Based on the fore thought on the burning problems of rural India such as farmersâ€™ suicides, infertility of land, drought related issues, unprecedented migration to cities and subsidiary impact on cities in terms of slum dwelling etc. a conference was organized to find solutions that could impact the farmers and generate sustainable methods to achieve economic and social turnaround. Surabhi Foundation organized a 3-day international conference in New Delhi with participation by people from various facets of society including scientists, leaders, businessmen, farmers, journalists, NGOs, social activists and thinkers. The conference was organized by Surabhi Foundation in collaboration with Indian Council of Agricultural Research (Ministry of Agriculture) on â€œHOLISTIC RURAL DEVELOPMENT THROUGH ORGANIC FARMINGâ€ on September 10 & 11 2009. Wholistic Rural Empowerment Program contributes directly to achieving the objectives of poverty and hunger alleviation through inclusive agricultural growth and improved nutrition. Cow based economy model aims to empower these farmers to become self dependent and earn a â€œrespectable and reliableâ€ self-sustainable livelihood. The first step in â€œCow Based Economyâ€ Model starts with enabling village households to own two cows each. This is possible through Micro-finance institutions that lend loans to villagers at attractive and viable conditions. Eventually, the loan shall be repaid from the cash-flows generated by various products of cow itself. Cow is a source of economic value as well as nutrition through its products. Cow-milk, which is a rich and balanced source of all nutrients, feeds the household, while surplus is sent to a â€œcentralizedâ€ village-exchange for further processing and for selling purposes. Village exchange is a central body run by villagers themselves to organize trade and help households with a ready collection and distribution-centre. Women empowerment by training on converting primary to secondary products were imparted: such as conversion of wheat to flour by hand milling, conversion of whole grains to pulses by using small machines, conversion of milk to ghee and other milk products. Training also focused good practices, quality requirement and cooperative working. We are working on artisan development and on creating self employment opportunities throughout the country. Involvement of educated youth from premier institutions across the nation such as IITs, IIMs, NIFTs etc. is a focus area for our organization. We have organized various programs for the same. Students are given research and development projects on important social causes. Surabhi Foundation ensures environmental sustainability in all its projects. In agriculture, the holistic farming techniques guarantee that the health of the soil is maintained, rather improved in some cases. Promotion of low energy technologies and renewable energy resources is undertaken in the cow based economy model.

detailsOfAchievement: Sursagar Society of Delhi Gharana Sursagar Society was founded in 1940 by the late Ustad Chand Khan Sahab/Saheb (Sangeet Martand) in the memory of his father Shams-e-Mousiqui Ustad Mamman Khan. The society aims to conserve and promote an awareness of both the rich and heterogeneous cultural tapestry through focus on the classical arts, with their attendant legends, rituals, mythology and philosophy and the deeper and subtler values of these arts. Sursagar Society of Delhi Gharanaâ€™s successful holding of the music festivals for more than 60 years has enhanced its prestige in the eyes of the public. The society has been organizing concerts in Delhi, Kolkata and Ranchi, and honoring outstanding artists with the objective of developing more interest in Indian Classical Music. The society also runs the Amir Khusro Institute of Music where free training is being provided to all those interested in any art form of Indian Classical Music. Since 1986(,) the society has been giving Ustad Chand Khan Awards to renowned artists for their outstanding contribution in the Art and Culture. Pt. Buddhadev Das Gupta, Dr. Shankar Lal Mishra, Guru Hare Krishna Behra are some of the renowned winners of the awards. In the past, great maestros like Smt Sitara Devi, Pt. detailsOfAchievement: SEEDS (Sustainable Environment and Ecological Development Society) is a national humanitarian agency that engages with the local communities in enhancing their resilience to environmental threats, such as extreme weather events, natural calamities etc. SEEDS is driven by the organizational vision of â€˜Building Resilient Communitiesâ€™. As a humanitarian organization, SEEDS works closely with the local government authorities and reaches out to communities that have been impacted by disasters. Going beyond relief, SEEDS has helped them adapt to future such events through process of raising awareness, learning, introduction of resilient technologies, weather monitoring etc. Such measures have helped strengthen the communityâ€™s coping capacities. Founded in 1994, SEEDS originated as a college based interest group in School of Planning and Architecture (SPA), Delhi, delving in research on environment and habitat issues. In the initial years, majority of the projects were actually the study undertaken to understand the depleting environment and its impact on communities. The core of this vision still remains. However, over the period of time SEEDS focused on Building Resilience through Disaster Risk Education; wherein acknowledging the depletion of eco systems and environment as the inherent cause for perpetuating disasters. The Gujarat earthquake of 2001 was a major turning point, when SEEDS got fully involved in relief and rehabilitation activities. Support was mobilised from a wide range of donor agencies, NGOs, academic institutions, governments and individuals to create a model rehabilitation project in Patan district, Gujarat. The success of the project, wherein people built their own homes their own ways with their own designs and measured inputs from SEEDS to ensure earthquake resistance, paved the way for sustained disaster management programmes not only in Gujarat, but also to other vulnerable states in the hill and coastal regions of the country. SEEDS has worked in more than 12 emergencies and have been able to achieve highest level of professionalism and quality in all its endeavors. This is attributed to its team of young professionals consisting of planners, architects, engineers, project management specialists and media experts. SEEDS is governed and advised by a board of eminent academicians and practitioners from international organization. SEEDS, primarily engages in shelter reconstruction and adopts locally based approaches to reduce the impact of future disasters on vulnerable communities. Over the years, SEEDS has constructed more than 5000 houses and restored over 50 schools across the country. Today, SEEDS continues to advocate for and work with communities across Asia to build a safer and more sustainable world. SEEDS is a member of National Platform for Disaster Risk Reduction (NPDRR) constituted by Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India. It is the first Indian agency to be certified by â€œHumanitarian Accountability Partnershipsâ€ â€“ which is signatory to the Code of Conduct for the International Red Cross and Red Crescent. SEEDS Indiaâ€™s long term Rehabilitation Project after Gujarat Earthquake, focused on participatory rehabilitation and reconstruction in Patanka Village in Patan District of Gujarat was termed by United Nations as an International best Practice in Rehabilitation. The project was also covered as a good practice on community disaster resilience in the world disaster report 2004. In 2010, SEEDS was adjudged as â€˜Indian of the Yearâ€™ in the public Service category by CNN IBN for its efforts in Leh. SEEDS holds key membership in almost all national and internal networks working towards of Disaster risk reduction including International Red Cross and Red Cresent, Asian Disaster Risk Reduction Network, Sphere etc.

detailsOfAchievement: Over the years TERI has developed a wider interpretation of this core purpose and its application. Consequently, TERI has created an environment that is enabling, dynamic and inspiring for the development of solutions to global problems in the fields of energy, environment and current patterns of development, which are largely unsustainable. The Institute has grown substantially over the years, particularly, since it launched its own research activities and established a base in New Delhi, its registered headquarters. The central element of TERIâ€™s philosophy has been its reliance on entrepreneurial skills to create benefits for society through the development and dissemination of intellectual property. The strength of the Institute lies in not only identifying and articulating intellectual challenges straddling a number of disciplines of knowledge but also in mounting research, training and demonstration projects leading to development of specific problem-based advanced technologies that help carry benefits to society at large.

detailsOfAchievement: The Himalaya Trust, THT, has been working since 1993 with the mountain people of Uttarakhand, India on issues of environmental and natural resource degradation and regeneration which threaten the self-sufficient existence of small highland village communities and tangibly connecting people lives and livelihood to the above. Vision: The Trust vision is to ensure social, economic and environmental sustainability for remote Himalayan village communities through environmental and social action which leads to greater community well-being. Our mission is to support and strengthen grassroots initiatives undertaken by local groups or individuals which promote conservation of natural resources and lead to an improvement in the quality of life of the community within their natural habitat and cultural setting. The Himalaya Trust encourages communities to develop a sense of pride and an attitude of trusteeship towards their unique ecological, intellectual and cultural heritage. THT explores locally feasible economic solutions for mountain communities as an alternative to the persistent migration to the plains for employment, To revitalize traditional knowledge of communities and practices of mountain cultures essential for their well being and social and economic stability, To strengthen and energize grassroots institutions to take action to reinforce and enrich their natural biodiversity and water sources through micro-watershed planning. We are proud that the founder of the Organization, Mr. Nalni Jayal is considered to be the motivating force in the establishment of the Environment Ministry in India and in close collaboration with the then Gvoernment, was credited with the establishment of all of our country wild life and biodiversity sanctuaries. Associated with the work, there are interventions on Health, Education, Agriculture and Water. Oral testimony that gave us a peek into our past and the deployment of Community Radio project, pioneered by THT in the region. THT has partnered donors like The Hans foundation, Tata Trust, HIMMOTTHAN Society, Swajal, WWF, UNDP, Ministry of Environment & Forests, PANOS London, UNESCO, Equal Access, World Space USA Room to Read, Terre des Hommes, UGVS-IL&FS, GIZ etc. THT has been focused on activities based on community needs, hence, implemented many modest but successful projects in Uttarakhand. Community Radio, Intensive Agriculture, PIL on Environmental issues and dealing on the ground, Oral Testimonies are some of our success stories along with Communication and Culture program.

detailsOfAchievement: INCLEN is a unique global network of clinical epidemiologists, biostatisticians, health social scientists, health economists and other health professionals affiliated with key academic healthcare institutions. INCLEN is dedicated to improving the health of disadvantaged populations, particularly in low- and middle-income countries, by promoting equitable healthcare based on the best evidence of effectiveness and the efficient use of resources. At national level, the INCLEN units work closely with the Government of India and State Governments. INCLEN has formal MOU with Indian Council of Medical Research, and Government of Haryana. INCLEN has also strong and active linkages with several national and international universities, research organizations and professional associations. INCLEN has also established a demographic, development, health and environmental surveillance site (DDESS) - SOMAARTH (Synergizing Economic Development and Comprehensive Health) in Palwal district of Haryana, about 80 km from Delhi. SOMAARTH DESS site is comprised of 51 villages with about 200,000 populations. Several community based projects are underway in this DESS site. The Data Management Unit at INCLEN Executive Office has a senior program officer, one program officer, one junior statistician and two data assistants. INCLEN has state of art computing facilities with a large number of computers, two dedicated servers, lease lines for high speed internet connectivity both in Delhi office in SOMAARTH DDESS, and data management software, including statistical analysis software (STATA 12.0 SE). INCLEN has moved in to paperless data collection approach for the last 1.5 years. INCLEN has developed in-house software for analysis of qualitative data â€“IQ-DAS (INCLEN Qualitative Data Analysis Software) based on our experience of last 18 years. All qualitative data is now analyzed using this software. INCLEN has now added a spatial epidemiology data analytic capability with a program officer in medical geography. INCLEN has successfully completed four different research studies recently viz., determinants of under nutrition in children (in 6 states of India); assessing the cold chain system (in Kerala, Gujarat and Bihar states of India covering 27 districts and all cold chain points) and Neuro-developmental disabilities (NDDs) among children (in 5 zones across 10 states of India).

sourceOfFunds.purpose: The present work aims at studying efficacy of fixed duration MDT using Real time RT-PCR technology

The study will be to look into the anti-inflammatory mechanism in patients in relation to 11?-HSD expression and activity, cytokine response, ApoE levels and its phenotype, levels of circulating markers to understand the underlying mechanism of inflammation that leads nerve damage.

The proposed study is supposed to add valuable information in addressing the question of existence of pockets of endemic areas in different parts of India and continuous new case detection in the population. This can be possible by investigating methods to identify effectively the genotype of M.leprae strains from different sources and tracing the mode of transmission.
The Study is to diagnose the medico-psycho-social pathology of the leprosy afflicted after occurremce of symptoms.

Our study will add some valuable information to develop a link between the level of vitamin D and leprosy spectrum and reactions.
The present attempt is just for developing a test for early diagnosis of leprosy.

A Predictive biomarker for prediction of inflammatory reactions in leprosy has long been desired. This project envisages the identification and analysis of certain novel immune molecules and T cell subsets involved in the skin immune surveillance and regulation of inflammatory episodes in the borderline forms of Leprosy (BT, BB and BL).
This study will decipher the functional properties of auto-reaction in the leprosy patients and will throw some light on the mechanism by which auto-reaction is induced in leprosy patients with T1R.

detailsOfAchievement: The Leprosy Mission Trust India has 141 years of dedicated service amongst the poorest and most ostracized communities through low cost quality healthcare, vocational training for sustainable livelihoods and education and community development interventions in some of the poorest districts in India through 14 hospitals, 6 vocational training centers, various community development projects, 2 leprosy homes, research lab etc. â€¢ Leprosy Medical & Surgical Care: In 2014 alone 75,522 outpatient consultations for leprosy care, 7,104 admissions for specialized leprosy care and conducted 3,351 leprosy related surgeries were done. â€¢ General Healthcare to communities: 466,118 outpatient general consultations; 9,332 admissions for medical, surgical, obstetric and ophthalmic care were done. â€¢ In 2014 - 1,346 underprivileged young people enrolled in TLMTIâ€™s institution based and community based livelihoods skills training courses. â€¢ Education: In 2014, 1,182 underprivileged young people were able to continue their school, college and professional education because of TLMTIâ€™s financial assistance program. â€¢ In 2014, through TLMTIâ€™s community development interventions: 7,236 people from marginalised communities were assisted with income generating activities; 1,295 Self Help Groups were formed and supported for community mobilization; 137,558 women from marginalized communities were supported through empowerment initiatives; 13,790 people affected by leprosy were supported through development and leprosy care initiatives; 12,543 people with disabilities were supported through development and disability management initiatives. â€¢ TLMTIâ€™s state of the art Immunology Research Laboratory is a recognised WHO and National Drug Resistance Surveillance centre for leprosy and trains PhD students and other post-graduates in advanced laboratory research. â€¢ In 2015 TLMTI was a joint winner of the prestigious Times of India Social Impact Award in the Health Category. â€¢ TLMTI sensitized the Law Commission of India regarding the discriminatory laws against people affected by leprosy as a result of which the Law Commission in 2015, has recommended to the Government the Eliminating Discrimination Against People affected by Leprosy Bill and Social Inclusion of people affected by leprosy and their families. â€¢ TLMTI is committed to its mission and the potential to further it through a broad range of strategic partnerships/collaborations e.g. the NLEP under the Ministry of Health, the WHO, the International Federation of Anti-leprosy Associations (ILEP), The National Human Rights Commission and the National Commission for Women.

detailsOfAchievement: The Nabha Foundation has been established in response to a felt need for a holistic pattern of development in Punjab. It seeks to bring together multiple stakeholders, the state and union governments, national and international development agencies, academic and research institutions and above all, the people on the ground, to engage in a creative dynamic of action. The Foundation takes up issues of integrated and sustainable rural development, infrastructure up gradation and heritage conservation in Nabha, Punjab. The target audience of the Foundationâ€™s work is the general population of the Nabha block, and especially women, children and the marginalized groups and individuals. Vision: An equitable, prosperous and humane society embodying the principles of holistic and sustainable development inspired by traditions of community and civic leadership. Mission: The Nabha Foundation promotes innovative rural development models for the prosperity, development and well being of the people of Nabha and its surrounding areas in Punjab. It is our hope that people in India and across the world can benefit from these models.
